column1: What will be Russia's 2019 military expenditure as a percentage of GDP, according to SIPRI?
column5: ['Less than 4.4%', 'Between 4.4% and 4.9%, inclusive', 'More than 4.9% but less than 5.5%', 'Between 5.5% and 6.0%, inclusive', 'More than 6.0%']
column6: ['Non-US Politics']
column11: This question will be resolved using data reported by SIPRI. According to SIPRI, Russia's 2016 military expenditures were 5.3% of GDP. The question will be suspended on 31 December 2019 and resolved when the data are first released, typically in the spring of the following year. Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: Russia has been running its military on a relative shoestring, so a massive spike is unlikely. Based on what it looks like GDP will be this year, and based on recent history and trends (2016 needs to be adjusted for a one-time payment), coming in below 5% seems highly likely, and for it to even hit 4.4% would require a big spending increase.

Using data since 1992, the average annual value is 3.8%, with a standard deviation of 0.6%. These probabilities assume that distribution remains valid looking forward. An argument might be made to adjust given that the last several years have been higher than the long term average, but I think it's a fool's game to guess which way to adjust; an increase above last year (3.7%) might make sense to reflect recent trends, but then again a decrease also makes sense from the point of view of reverting to the mean.

@Anneinak Shortly after the start of Putin’s fourth term tax raises and a higher retirement age were announced, which lead to drastic declines in his approval ratings. Indeed, to keep public budgets stable, the Russian government is forced to raise taxes and extend the retirement age in the years to come. As long as the standard of living was rising, the vast majority of Russian refrained from active participation in politics. But then from 2014 to 2018, real incomes fell for five years running. Kremlin could now be facing a crisis of legitimacy – and that in a phase of uncertainty about a possible shift of power after Putin’s last term of office (2018–2024). Putin has said he wants to raise living standards and improve social care in Russia, and a cut to military spending is one way to make funds available for such projects this. Further, the reform proposed by the former Minister of Finance Alexei Kudrin recommends increasing spending on infrastructure, education, and health care, and decreasing spending on defense, security, and a number of subsidies. Against this backdrop, Kremlin will less likely reduce its defense budget since the Russian arms industry employs around two million workers, whose support for the Kremlin regime is essential. Also, cutting the defense budget contradicts the Kremlin’s current political priorities by glorifying the success of the military buildup. As it concerns Syria and Ukraine: According to estimates, the direct costs of Russian military operations in Syria and Ukraine make up just a few percents of the Russian defense budget, which amounted to around €43.3 billion in 2017. The necessary expenditures could thus be covered entirely through reallocations, for instance from the budget for military exercises, without any added burden on the budget. Again, it is less likely that Kremlin will cut DB or even less likely that it will increase DB beyond 4.4%. Probably it will remain the same or bwn 4.0 and 4.2%

Russia has spent 903 billion roubles on defense for the first three months of this year according to the Ministry of Finance [1]. This represents a year-on-year increase on Q1 2018 of 13%. It is worth noting that defense is a sub-category within military expenditure as I have explained previously [2]. This notwithstanding, what does a 13% increase tell us about possible military spending in 2019?
The preliminary official estimate of Russian GDP growth for 1Q19 is 0.5% y/y, which is well below the 1.2% y/y consensus and our 1.1% y/y expectations.

Looking at SIPRI's database of military expenditures as a percentage of GDP through 2018 for Russia, it would appear that after steadily increasing beginning in 2008, the percentage began to decline beginning in 2016. In conducting my own research and looking at GDP growth in Russia, the GDP seems to be decreasing. Russian defense spending is focused on sustainability, Russian's are not interested in increasing military expenditures especially while GDP decreases and possibly endangering their economy. Therefore it is likely that military expenditures in Russia as a share of GDP in 2019 will decline, furthermore, I believe that it will decline from the current percentage of 3.9% placing it in the catefory of less than 4.4%.

The historical data shows only rare instances of military expenditure exceeding 4.0% ,and steadily decreasing since 2016. If Russia increases to more that 4.4%, it will be due to an unforeseen issue arising and forcing Russia to increase for the sake of her threatened security. As the world currently stands, I don't see any pressing reasons for the Russia to jump up almost an entire percent.

No change or it will increase slightly with USD 1bn, around USD 62.5 bn or 4.0% from GDP since the oil price has not been changed much in comparison with 2018. In the longer term, the Kremlin is expected to begin gradually increasing its defense budget in 2021 — though not at a rate that would permit an immediate return to pre-2017 levels.
Military expenditure by all 29 NATO members amounted to just over half of global spending, SIPRI added.

Between 1992 and 2018 (a 26-year span), Russian military spending was an average of 3.91% per GDP. The percentage decreased by 23% between 2016 and 2017 and by 5% between 2017 and 2018. This shows two trends: first, military spending is rarely above 4.4% of GDP and it has been decreasing since 2016. Russian military spending has only been equal or above 4.4% of GDP four times in that time period and the spending drop between 2016 and 2017 is the largest since the period between 1997 and 1998, when military spending as a percentage of GDP decreased by 32.5%. The largest increases were 25.8% between 2008 and 2009, 19.5% between 2014 and 2015, and 14.8% between 1998 and 1999 while the majority of increases were between 2 and 9% of GDP. An increase to 4.4% of GDP from the current level of 3.9% would be an overall increase of 12.8, which has not happened during this time period: the closest was that 14.8% increase between 1998 and 1999. Therefore, while there is a chance that Russian military spending as a percentage of GDP will be 4.4% or larger, that is very unlikely.
Russian budgets are a shell game. Also oil likely to stay high while imports depressed meaning economy growth (more bang for buck from military budget)

This hinges on two factors: stability of the Russian economy and the military expenditure the Russian government would like to remain at. According to the World Bank, the Russian economy is projected to grow 1.5%-1.8% in 2019 and 2020, but this could change depending on global oil and gas prices. Russian military spending, both in Rouble and GDP %, was increasing since Putin took back the Russian presidency in 2012 but, as the effects of both economic sanctions and the downturn of the Russian economic in 2014, has decreased since 2017. That being said, with new economic projects, as well as improved relations with different countries allied with Russia, there is reason to assume this slump will change course in 2019 and military spending will increase.

Ceteris Paribus, Russian defense spending as a share of GDP will continue to decline into 2019. Russia faces serious domestic economic concerns (i.e. degraded infrastructure, over reliance on energy exports, rising poverty) that will curb its ability to devote more resources to its military. This, however, does not necessarily suggest the long term degradation of Russia military power. Russia's military relies on conscripts, which means that outside of the money needed to provide initial training, it does not necessarily need to devote as much money to funding year round readiness, or invest as heavily in training like its Western competitors with more professional armed services. Instead, it devotes more of its defense budget to R&D, procurement, and modernization. While all of these initiatives have significant up front expenses, their true costs can be spread out over a longer time horizon. This helps Russia keep its military spending low. Finally, Russia is undoubtedly itching to find a way to withdraw its military forces from Syria. Although the intervention has been hugely successful for Putin, and it has considerably raised his domestic and international standing, he knows that once events "go South" (i.e. Russian death toll increases in country) these gains will erode. Therefore, Putin will most likely seek a way to extricate Russia/himself from a hard military presence in Syria, thereby further decreasing Russian military spending in 2019.

From 2014 to 2016 there was a significant increase in Russia's defense spending from 4.1% to 5.5%, which can most likely be attributed to Russia annexation in Crimea which began in 2014. Although the percentage was 5.3% in 2016, which is not a major difference from 5.5%, in 2017, Russia's defense spending budget as a percentage of GDP was 4.3%. This is a significant drop. Based on Russia's past defense spending as a percentage of GDP, 2016 was its highest spending year whereas from 1992 to 2015, Russia's spending ranged as low as 3% but did not surpass 5%. As such, it is unlikely that we are to see a dramatic increase in Russia's defense budget, unless significant conflict occurs. If significant conflict occurs toward the end of 2019, it is foreseeable that spending increases. See: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ms.mil.xpnd.gd.zs?end=2017&start=1994.

Additionally Russia has had to mitigate sanctions in the midst of modernizing their soviet-era defenses. Russia currently has some serious economic issues to overcome and expanding their military expenditures is not going to be the best use of their resources. Russia is coming off of a large amount of modernization, so they can take a step back and cut military expenditures by merely maintaining and supplying.

Using SIPRI's excel spreadsheet of all of Russia's military expenditures as a percentage of GDP, I created a box-and-whisker plot to show a range of all percentages since 1988. First, what I found was that 2016 was an outlier year. It was the only percentage to break 5% in this period. Second, the upper limit was 4.9% (excluding the 2016, the outlier, of course) with a lower limit of 3.0%. The median was 3.9%, while the mean was 4.0%, and the upper quartile was 4.3%, which goes to show how typically low the budget is. In all fairness, it is important to note that from 2014 to 2017 (the most recent data available) the expenditure percentage was higher than the mean, but only 2015 and 2016 broke even a 4.4% expenditure. As a result of all of this, I am very doubtful of another outlier year, and expect 2019 to be less than 4.9%. Given that the budget has only broken 4.4% five times in the 26 years we have data for, I am going with 75% "less than 4.4%" and 25% "4.4% to 4.9%", which is percentage that Russia has exceeded 4.4% in the past, plus a 5% bump due to ongoing conflicts that Russia is involved in.

Russia announced to spend 1.44 trillion roubles on military procurement [1]. Procurement is part of the larger category of the gosudarstvennyi oboronnyi zakaz (GOZ). Procurement comprises the vast majority of GOZ spending [2]. GOZ spending has in recent years (2014-2016) been about half of Russia's definition of 'total military spending' [2]. If this share persists, then we'd expect total military spending of 2.9 trillion roubles. This is largely in line with the assumption in my earlier forecast, which assumed total military spending of 2.8 trillion based on Russia's planned expenditure [3].

Russia is not an any position economically to increase military spending. Spending for 2017 was 4.3%, likely as a result of severe sanctions and drops in oil prices. 2018 data will be telling about what trend we may ultimately see, but current economic desperation is likely to necessitate cuts to Putin's military dreams for now. Increase above 4.9% is highly unlikely, and higher than 5.5% is politically and economically impossible.

Russia's military expenditure as % of GDP from 2013-2017 was: 3.9%, 4.1%, 4.9%, 5.5%, 4.3%. Since the end of the Cold War, it has not been higher than 5.5. And other than 2016, has never been higher than 4.9. Some factors that may promote increased defense expenditures include: the invalidation of the INF (although Russia was continuing to pursue expanded ballistic missile and nuclear modernization technologies in contravention to the treaty), the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, ongoing conflict in Syria, combating terrorism in Chechnya, and high dollar weapon technology projects. However, domestic turmoil is more likely to reduce (or maintain) Russia's overall expenditure from 2017's level of 4.3%. Russia's domestic economic situation is so bad as to require the government to raise the retirement age in the country, causing widespread unrest. Putin maintains a tight grip on power, but even he is not immune to domestic pressure.
Russia plans to focus on domestic issues in the next few years but this will not undercut military readiness as previous investments on military needs continues to be adequate.
I don't see Russia's military spending increasing. I would predict that it is probable a rate similar (or slightly larger/smaller) to 2016 is maintained.

Particularly in light of the recent withdrawals on the parts of Russia and the US from the INF treaty, there is a higher liklihood that Russia will either maintain or increase current military expenditure levels, rather than reducing. This also takes into account China's increasing global influence, including in places Russia has long considered satellite states.

Russia operates a lean military with skeleton brigades, minimal force projection, and outsourcing kinetic and covert action to private military contractors. This means that the military complex will be taking a "pay-cut". Compounded by all of this, there is brain drain, a shortage of contract soldiers (who are paid minuscule amounts compared to the US military), and a wariness of to engage in foreign adventures with conventional mil-mil force.

Russia's federal budget for 2017-2019, suggests a spending of 2.8 trillion roubles on "national defense" [1]. It is worth noting, however, that SIPR's definition of "military spending" is more expansive than the federal definition for "national defense", with SIPRI numbers consistently higher than "national defense" figures with the difference in the order of hundreds of billions of roubles. For example, SIPRI's definition includes spending for paramilitary forces and military pension payments [2], which are not covered by the federal government definition of "national defense". This paper [3, pages 17 and 23] provides a disambiguation of the terms.

Vedomosti 20 Sep. 2018: Defense spending will not change significantly in the next three years. But the budget expenses for the prosecutor’s office and the Investigative Committee will increase Over the next three years, defense spending will remain at about the same level as in 2018, follows from the federal budget bill for 2019–2021. (“Vedomosti” got acquainted with a copy of the document; its authenticity was confirmed by a federal official). So, in 2019, there is a reduction in expenditures under the section “National Defense” (includes the overwhelming part of defense expenditures) by 118 billion rubles, in 2020 an increase of 105 billion compared to 2019, and in 2021 - An increase of 141 billion compared with 2020. According to a person close to the Ministry of Defense, most likely, as in the past year, the ministry will raise the issue of increasing allocations in the range of 100–200 billion rubles. and, probably, this request will be partially satisfied. In this case, there will be no nominal reduction in defense spending, but in fact, taking into account inflation, they will be reduced. It is also not known how planned for 2020–2021. the increase in spending will be able to offset inflation, the source said.

2017 was the first year since 1998 where Russian military spending was decreasing from the year before (-20%), bringing it down to 4.3%, from 5.5% in 2016. Russia is still 4th largest military spender, with spending on the same level as 2014. According to SIPRI, the pattern of military spending over the past 10 years can be correlated with the rise and fall of oil prices. Armed conflict is also a driver, obviously. With increasing oil prices, will this mean an increase in russian expenditure (both relative and absolute) or will military spending be kept at same level, but there will be a relative decrease due to rising GDP?

I assign a more than even percent chance that the Russian Federation will increase its military spending budget in terms of GDP from the previous level of 4.3% to anywhere between the 4.4-4.9% range. My reasoning is based on the positive trend in the crude oil price that has continued since 2016, increased engagement in the African continent leading to increased exports, and the gradual reduction of Russian presence in Syria following the end of major operations against ISIS.

The highest recorded military expenditure as a percentage of GDP conducted by the Russian Federation was 5.5% in 2016. Russia's 2019 military expenditures will focus on achieving near-parity to U.S. and Chinese capabilities in areas such as hypersonics. This will be balanced against Russia's strategic use of cyber and political warfare to achieve its desired aims. There has been expressed the desire to thaw U.S.-Russia relations and attempts to strengthen the Sino-Russian defense cooperation. Still, the leaders of the aforementioned nations view the world through a realist lens and will ultimately operate consistent with the principles of relative gains. The security dilemma that NATO poses for the Russian Federation will potentially drive GDP percentage expenditures for military over the 5% threshold.

Looking at both historical trends and the current environment, it can be seen that 2015 and 2016 were outliers for Russia in terms of military expenditure. They were typically allocating less than 4.4.% with a growth of around .3% per year. With the current economic situation within Russia and the lack of a direct conflict high intensity that would necessitate an outlier year (such as 2016) it can be expected that it would follow a similar trend. Having returned to the expected 4.2% in 2017, if this trend is followed than it would put it between 4.4 and 4.9. Slight growth would mean that it would remain under 4.4%, however with recent activity in Syria and the need to maintain a presence there it is likely that it will experience a healthy level of growth (relative to historical trends). Pressure by the United States in NATO allies to hit a benchmark goal in military expenditure may encourage Russia as well, as they look to embarrass NATO countries or simply to increase intimidation.

This is a numerator - denominator problem, and more specifically, an elasticity of the numerator to the denominator problem. Military spending growth lags government revenue growth, and government revenue growth lags oil price growth. Thus, I expect those speaking of oil price movements in late 2018 determining 2019 defense spending are likely going to overestimate the impact of the oil price moves. Second, the dollar (or ruble) amount of spending should really be seen as a real life set of assets and people being mobilized. Defense % of GDP is not a dial to turn based on geopolitical events. The amount of spending is not very easy to change. Thus, I used the average of the last three years as a base rate (Putin would have been of a different mind before 2015). It quickly showed that 2016 was an abnormal year. So I ignored 2016 and assumed the previous year ruble amount (not % GDP) plus some growth on the 2017 ruble GDP, using the latest assumed GDP growth rate of 1.9% (August).

Using Russia’s average military spending as a percentage of GDP since 1992 (based on SIPRI estimates)—4.0%—as a baseline, and considering last year’s drop in spending (both as a percentage of GDP and in absolute terms) corresponding with ongoing economic problems and the imposition of more international sanctions over the last few months, it seems likely that the trend will remain similar over the next year (https://money.cnn.com/2018/05/02/news/russia-defense-spending-plunge/index.html). Although, oil prices could mitigate that somewhat (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-27/oil-s-leap-toward-100-is-softening-the-blow-of-russia-sanctions).

Although the bellicose rhetoric coming out of Russia would suggest otherwise, in reality Russia's military spending has declined in 2017 as compared to 2016, and seems to be projected to drop again this year (2018). This does not mean Russia does not spend a lot of money as per its GDP, actually more than the United States. However, the economic woes within the Russian economy are real and have an impact even on their military expenditures. Dropping almost 20% from 2016 over 2017, I project that Russia's military spending as percentage of GDP is likely to drop within 4.4-4.9% for 2019. https://money.cnn.com/2018/05/02/news/russia-defense-spending-plunge/index.html https://www.newsweek.com/why-russia-cutting-military-spending-908069 https://www.nato.int/docu/review/2016/also-in-2016/does-russia-have-the-financial-means-for-its-military-ambitions/en/index.htm

Russia will likely maintain its current military spending strategy of partially funding proxy wars, building cyber warfare infrastructure and maintaining its nuclear arsenal. They are on a tight budget and the latter investments maintain and increase power cost effectively. The GDP of Russia in 2016 was 1.29 trillion dollars with a population of 144 million. Relative to the US and China, they are poor. Their major advantages are experience with a planned economy, academic infrastructure and deep seeded nationalism. Leverage created through oil and gas production and distribution is fading. A new squadron or any other type of heavy internal spending on equipment would be illogical, but they must spend enough to appear strong on the world stage.

3.8% in 2017 according to SIPRI. As the question states, it was 5.3% in 2016. That rules out the top 2 buckets.
Oil price increased therefore less % spend on arms.

Based on updated 2017 info from SIPRI, Russian military spending dropped precipitously. Even if 2018 and 2019 are better years economically, I don't seem them expanding military spending drastically enough to reach the higher ends of the question.

New 2017 SIPRI figs released today put Russia at 4.3% of GDP in 2017 https://www.sipri.org/databases/milex. I'd expected a drop back in my original forecast, although this is just under my preferred bucket at the moment. Consider it possible that the current increase in oil revenues could encourage some extra spending above this rate, SIPRI themselves note that oil exporters have cut generally in 2017 - so I'm not over-reacting and sticking with the 4.4 - 4.9 bucket mainly - also Kremlin plan was reported to be to drop and then ease back into the milex budget towards 2020. I also note upwards revisions for 2016 which could happen again, however feel even more so now that expenditure much over 5% is not sustainable in the long term. Doesn't necessarily mean that 2019 won't be another exceptional year, so keeping something in the higher buckets, just in case I need to make later revisions. Need to do more consideration of possible GDP growth.
I believe Russian military expenses will rise.
As a percent of GDP Russian military spending has been increasing pretty steadily by 0.2-0.4 per year this decade. Based on that I think we end up at 5.7%-5.8% in 2019.
increased oil revenues decrease percentage

10% less than 4.4%, 10% between 4.4% and 4.9%, 20% more than 4.9% but less than 5.5%, 50% between 5.5% and 6.0%, 10% more than 6% Russia has been increasing efforts in Syria as well as in other global arenas. They are also consistently attempting to increase their global image, and are known to place a large emphasis on military as a source of power. I feel that for this reason they will slightly increase their military spending. I do not feel that they will drastically increase it, as they have domestic needs to attend to as well.

SIPRI take account of all military-related expenditure including on pensions & paramilitary forces (any force that can be transferred to or serves the function of a military unit, so e.g. Rosgvardiya units fall under this, and certain FSB units, but I don't think the police do). This is higher than the often-reported expenditure per the Russian budget headings, which is why despite widely reported cuts (e.g. figs here https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-12-14/russia-s-military-is-leaner-but-meaner) the actual effect on SIPRI reported expenditure may not be so sharp.
Taking into account the "slow change" hypothesis, meaning the new numbers will not be too far away from the 5.3% of 2016.
This question is a ratio question: two estimates are made. First, will Russia increase/decrease its military expenditure. Second, what would be Russian GDP for 2019.
The figures will say what they want them to say.

This percentage decreases only if military spending decreases in current dollars or GDP rises rather a lot or both. Nobody believes that either of these conditions will be met over the next couple of years (depending of course on the faith one places in the numbers' accuracy). Movement in the other direction on both is more likely, the question being the magnitude of the shift(s). I foresee a need to tinker with my numbers early and often.

As others pointed out before me the number is essentially man-made. The question might be: What is a desireable number? Therefore large jumps seem unpreferrable, and an increase favorable to a decrease. This will require some updating over the coming months
